evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the preliminary historical timeline, indicating the issue was present and observable in this context.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains a robust explanation for the incident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary history, with no evidence or alternative explanations sufficiently undermining this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, such as miscommunication, lack of coordination, and procedural lapses documented in the preliminary history.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the preliminary historical timeline, indicating the issue was present and observable in this context.

defeaters: Explicit evidence of miscommunication or coordination failure among crew during the incident
Statements or reports indicating crew confusion or communication errors

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows communication between flight crew and headset operator and interaction between tug instructor and trainee, but no explicit indication of communication or coordination breakdown among crew is present; the incident of the aircraft moving beyond the TRP suggests a possible coordination issue but is not directly linked to communication breakdown (H1-H4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct evidence of communication breakdown; ambiguity in whether the incident was caused by communication/coordination issues

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows communication between flight crew and headset operator (H1), a changeover between trainee and instructor (H2, H3), and a procedural lapse where the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit a barrier (H4). These indicate some miscommunication and coordination issues consistent with the claim, but direct explicit statements of breakdown are not present.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit statements about miscommunication or procedural lapses; reliance on inferred coordination issues

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains a robust explanation for the incident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary history, with no evidence or alternative explanations sufficiently undermining this root cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
